com.github.mmichaelis.hamcrest.nextdeed.concurrent

Class Probe

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.github.mmichaelis.hamcrest.nextdeed.concurrent.Probe

  • public final class Probe
extends Object

    Utility class for launching probes on a system.

    Assert/Assume/Require:

    When to use which validation of the system under test?

    Assert:
    Use this if you are about to test that the system reaches the requested state. On failure your test case will be marked as Failure.
    Assume:
    Use this for programmatically ignoring your tests (instead of using for example annotations). On failure your test case will be marked as Ignored.
    Require:
    In tests use this to check for preconditions which, if failed, will prevent you from doing your actual test. On failure your test case will be marked as Error.
    Example:
    
 Probe.<System, State>probing(systemUnderTest)
      .withinMs(1000L);
      .assertThat(new Function<System,State>(){...}, equalTo(RUNNING));

    Mind that it is required to add the generic type parameters to probing — which in return will keep you from using static import for probing. The advantage is that you see right at the start what is your system under test and what is the state type you will wait for.

    Note:

    This class can be compared to Hamcrest's MatcherAssert. So whenever you want to assert/assume/require giving some grace period to the system under test this class is the one you should choose.

    Since:
    1.0.0
